intro: Oxytropis pseudosuavis, commonly known as the sweetvetch, is a member of the legume family Fabaceae. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in dry, rocky soils across the western United States. The plant features slender, branching stems and small, compound leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are typically pink or purple, arranged in clusters, and it produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. Oxytropis pseudosuavis is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitats.
